Legal_Issue: Whether Mr. Cheung met the residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Mr. Cheung was absent from Canada for 1,054 days during the four-year period before applying; held a Returning Resident Permit and maintained ties to Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; Mr. Cheung deemed eligible for Canadian citizenship
Court_Ruling: The appeal judge concluded that absences were temporary and residency in Canada was established
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada exceeding 1,000 days within the required period
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of citizenship due to alleged failure to meet minimum physical presence requirement
Legal_Standard: Minimum three years (1,095 days) of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Assessment_Factor: Nature and purpose of absences, maintenance of residential ties in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from citizenship judgeâ€™s decision via trial de novo
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; evidence of ties to Canada accepted
Evidence_Used: Returning Resident Permit, proof of property ownership, family ties, employment links in Canada
Application_Basis: Accrual of residency days under the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and character of absences, strength of connections to Canada
Relief_Sought: Overturning of citizenship refusal and approval of application
Governing_Rule: An applicant must have been physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days within the four years preceding the application
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Initial determination found insufficient residency days
Outcome: Appeal granted; eligibility for citizenship confirmed
Harm_Assessment: Unjust denial of citizenship rights based on strict interpretation of residency
Cause_Description: Mr. Cheung's application was denied due to insufficient residency days as per the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Handling: Comprehensive review of all evidence regarding travel and residential ties
Evidence_Issues: Dispute over whether absences were temporary or broke continuity of residence
Residency_Compliance: Initially found non-compliant; ultimately determined compliant due to temporary nature of absences
Evidence_Assessment: Absences considered temporary; strong residential ties supported continued residency status
Decision_Rationale: Despite lengthy absences, Mr. Cheung maintained significant ties to Canada, indicating intent to reside permanently
Evidentiary_Issues: Weight given to Returning Resident Permit and ongoing personal/economic ties
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' under the Citizenship Act including intent and continuity
